title: 104_s282
content: The "Domestic Violence Community Response Team Act of 1995" aims to establish partnerships between law enforcement and community groups to assist domestic violence victims, provide early intervention services to prevent future incidents, and create a central technical assistance center for programmatic information. Grants are authorized for community response teams. The "Domestic Violence Community Response Team Act of 1995" authorizes the Secretary of Health and Human Services to award grants to eligible entities for domestic violence prevention. Grants are limited to $500,000 and awarded for up to 3 years to nonprofit organizations with expertise in domestic violence prevention. The "Domestic Violence Community Response Team Act of 1995" authorizes grants to eligible entities for domestic violence prevention. Eligible entities must understand and reflect the diversity of the community they serve. Community response teams established under this act provide advocates to work in conjunction with service providers and support agencies. The "Domestic Violence Community Response Team Act of 1995" authorizes grants for community advocates to assist victims of domestic violence in various ways, including providing immediate support, educating victims about legal processes, safety arrangements, and resources, offering follow-up services and counseling, educating victims about abuse tactics, and partnering with law enforcement agencies. Applications for grants under this act are accepted from eligible entities that reflect the diversity of the community they serve. Applications for grants under the "Domestic Violence Community Response Team Act of 1995" require submission to the Secretary with a detailed plan for a community-based partnership between law enforcement and organizations, demonstrating leadership, commitment, and project evaluation. The "Domestic Violence Community Response Team Act of 1995" requires written reports and analysis to apply successful programs to other communities. Understanding the population served, including racial, ethnic, and socio-economic characteristics, is crucial. Administrative expenses for a community response team grant should not exceed 5% of the total amount. The "Technical Assistance Center" is established under the "Domestic Violence Community Response Team Act of 1995" to provide support and guidance for successful program implementation in different communities. The Secretary can award a contract to an eligible nonprofit organization to serve as a technical assistance center under the Domestic Violence Community Response Team Act of 1995. The center will provide national information, training, and support for community response teams, as well as technical assistance and training for local programs on domestic violence prevention. The Secretary can award a contract to an eligible nonprofit organization to serve as a technical assistance center under the Domestic Violence Community Response Team Act of 1995. The entity selected must demonstrate competence, experience, and support from community-based domestic violence organizations. Up to 5% of the funding for the technical assistance center can be used for administrative expenses. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 1996, 1997, and 1998 under this Act is set at $5,000,000, with $300,000 allocated for a contract under section 4.
